column4: but now I found out there is a kill switch that I need to turn off, the question is how
again, same message, kill switch must be turned off, HOW

The last two lines were a worry, but Jacques Vuillemin suggested that Fn-F2 is the magic to turn off the Kill Switch. If this doesn't work then modify the BIOS (F2 on boot) to disable the wireless hotley. The wireless load command worked for me after Fn-F2.
great, that bit doesn't work for me, the Fn+f2 bit doesn't work, and the BIOS has no option
yeah, I need to get that to work too
anyhow, someone said "I use to type "setkeycodes" command follow by pressing "Wireless Button" to make it change to rf_kill = "0"" what does he mean?
I do have a hardware switch
it's Fn+F2, doesn't work in ubuntu
if it doesn't work, that's a bug and needs filing in the bug tracker
perhaps there is a hardware switch on one of the sides of the laptop aswell (as in physical switch)
dude, no, don't format.  that doesn't solve anything
Ginks: I'm confused, which one of you has the Asus A5E
can you do  'sudo acpi_listen'   and then try pressing the Fn-F2 combination
the Unix way is to print errors, but not success
